questions.prompt: The fundamental frequency ω₀ for a signal with period T is:
questions.explanation: The fundamental angular frequency is ω₀ = 2π/T rad/s. In Hz, it would be f₀ = 1/T. All other harmonics are integer multiples of this frequency: 2ω₀, 3ω₀, 4ω₀, etc.

questions.prompt: A square wave contains which harmonics?
questions.explanation: Due to half-wave symmetry, a square wave has only odd harmonics: 1st, 3rd, 5th, etc. The coefficients decrease as 1/k, so higher harmonics contribute less. This creates the characteristic 'ringing' at transitions.

questions.prompt: c₀ in the Fourier series represents:
questions.explanation: c₀ is the average value (DC) of the signal over one period: c₀ = (1/T)∫x(t)dt. It's the 0th 'harmonic'—a constant offset. For signals symmetric about zero, c₀ = 0.

questions.prompt: Sinusoids are eigenfunctions of LTI systems because:
questions.explanation: When a sinusoid e^(jωt) goes through an LTI system, output is H(ω)·e^(jωt)—same frequency, just scaled. The system cannot create new frequencies. This is why Fourier analysis is so powerful for LTI systems.

questions.prompt: For a real-valued signal, the coefficients satisfy:
questions.explanation: Real signals have conjugate symmetric coefficients: c₋ₖ = cₖ*. This ensures that when positive and negative exponentials combine, imaginary parts cancel and the result is real. Magnitude spectrum is even: |cₖ| = |c₋ₖ|.
The magnitude |cₖ| gives the amplitude (strength) of the k-th harmonic. The angle ∠cₖ gives its phase. Together they fully describe how much of each frequency is present and when it peaks.

questions.prompt: A signal with half-wave symmetry x(t) = -x(t+T/2) has:
questions.explanation: Half-wave symmetry means the signal is its own negative after half a period. This forces even harmonics to zero. Square waves and triangle waves have this symmetry, which is why they contain only odd harmonics.

questions.prompt: The Fourier series converges to x(t) if x(t) satisfies:
questions.explanation: Dirichlet conditions: x(t) is bounded, has finite discontinuities and extrema per period. Most practical signals satisfy these. At discontinuities, the series converges to the midpoint of the jump.

questions.prompt: The exponential Fourier series formula is:
questions.explanation: The exponential form x(t) = Σcₖe^(jkω₀t) uses complex exponentials at harmonic frequencies. The sum is from k = -∞ to +∞. This compact form is preferred for analysis because it leads to simpler derivations.

questions.prompt: For a periodic signal, the spectrum is:
questions.explanation: Periodic signals have discrete spectra—energy only at harmonic frequencies kω₀. Plotted as a 'line spectrum' with sticks at k = ...-2,-1,0,1,2... This contrasts with aperiodic signals which have continuous spectra.
